questions.text: A 34-year-old male patient presents with right sided discomfort, redness of eye, blurring of the vision ,and complains of seeing halos. He has no comorbidities and no significant past history. On examination, the intraocular pressure was 45 mm Hg, aqueous flare, along with some keratic precipitates inferiorly. What is the diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Glaucomatocyclitic crisis This is a case of glaucomatocyclitic crisis, which is an acute, recurrent uveitis with secondary glaucoma . Patients present with unilateral mild ocular discomfort, some blurring of vision, and halos with open angles. The intraocular pressure is often between 40 and 50 mm Hg. Inflammation is minimal, with some aqueous flare, occasional cells, and a few small, flat, non pigmented keratic precipitates inferiorly.

Highyeild:

Glaucomatocyclitic crisis attacks resolve in days to weeks, and recurrence is common.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A. Fuchs heterochromic iridocyclitis consists of chronic, low-grade iritis with posterior subcapsular cataract and secondary glaucoma. It is associated with a change in colour of the iris. The inflammation consists of low-grade flares and cells, with stellate keratic precipitates and fine filaments scattered over the entire endothelium. Anterior vitreous opacities and occasionally small white nodules may be present on the anterior surface of the iris. The vignette has a shorter history and no signs suggestive of cataracts or heterochromia. Option: C. Phacolytic glaucoma refers to secondary open-angle glaucoma if the lens has been damaged or if lens proteins from a hypermature senile cataract escape into the aqueous. Cortical lens matter excites a reaction by phagocytes, which engulf the lens particles. These cells are swept into the trabecular spaces by the normal current of aqueous, where they block the exit of aqueous from the eye. Option: D. Neovascular glaucoma follows extensive retinal ischaemia and is commonly seen in association with central retinal vein obstruction ( CRVO ) and proliferative diabetic retinopathy. It is due to the presence of neovascularization over the iris (rubeosis iridis) and consequent fibrosis , leading to zip-like adhesions of the iris to the cornea at the angle. There is no history of CRVO or diabetes in this case.

Extraedge:

Glaucomatocycitic crisis aka Posner-Schlossman syndrome. Management Medical Therapy: First-Line Therapy include topical beta blockers such as timolol, alpha agonists such as brimonidine, and carbonic anhydrase inhibitors such as dorzolamide. For control of inflammation, a topical steroid drop such as prednisolone acetate 1% is used. Surgical Therapy: It is considered when medical therapy fails.

questions.text: A 58-year-old patient presents with a sudden onset headache and blurred vision. There is a significant past history of sudden, painless loss of vision, and he was diagnosed with central retinal vein occlusion, for which he was treated, and his vision improved. His IOP is 38 mm Hg. What is the patient likely suffering from?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Neovascular glaucoma Neovascular glaucoma follows extensive retinal ischaemia and is commonly seen in association with central retinal vein obstruction (CRVO) and proliferative diabetic retinopathy. It is due to the presence of neovascularization over the iris (rubeosis iridis) and consequent fibrosis, leading to zip-like adhesions of the iris to the cornea at the angle.

Highyeild:

Treatment consists of anti-VEGF agents and retinal photocoagulation or cryotherapy to eliminate the stimulus for neovascularization. The raised intraocular pressure can be alleviated by a trabeculectomy, anti-fibroblastic agents, or an anterior chamber drainage implant.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A. Uveitic glaucoma is a form of secondary open-angle glaucoma . It results from swelling and dysfunction of the endothelial cells or infiltration and obstruction of the trabecular meshwork by inflammatory material such as white blood cell aggregates, macrophages, lymphocytes, and fibrin. This leads to a diminished outflow of aqueous with a subsequent rise in intraocular pressure. As there is no history suggestive of uveitis and with a history of CRVO, the diagnosis of neovascular glaucoma is correct . Option: B. Phacolytic glaucoma refers to secondary open-angle glaucoma if the lens has been damaged or if lens proteins from a hypermature senile cataract escape into the aqueous. Cortical lens matter excites a reaction by phagocytes, which engulf the lens particles. These cells are swept into the trabecular spaces by the normal current of aqueous, where they block the exit of aqueous from the eye. Since there is no history suggestive of cataractous changes , it is not phacolytic glaucoma. Option: C. Fuchs heterochromic iridocyclitis consists of a chronic, low-grade iritis with posterior subcapsular cataract and secondary glaucoma. It is associated with a change in the colour of the iris. The inflammation consists of low-grade flares and cells, with stellate keratic precipitates and fine filaments scattered over the entire endothelium. The vignette has no signs suggestive of cataracts or heterochromia.

Extraedge:

The prognosis of neovascular glaucoma is generally poor , as it often occurs in advanced stages of underlying eye diseases and can lead to irreversible vision loss. Early diagnosis and treatment prevent the progression of the disease.

questions.text: Which of the following is true about phacolytic glaucoma?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Secondary open angle glaucoma Phacolytic glaucoma refers to secondary open angle glaucoma if the lens has been damaged or if lens proteins from a hypermature senile cataract escape into the aqueous. Cortical lens matter excites a reaction by phagocytes , which engulf the lens particles.

Highyeild:

These cells are swept into the trabecular spaces by the normal current of aqueous, where they block the exit of aqueous from the eye.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A . The lens becomes intumescent in phacomorphic glaucoma . The swollen lens obliterates the drainage angle by forcing the root of the iris against the cornea. Option: C . Secondary angle closure glaucoma occurs due to phacotopic glaucoma and phacomorphic glaucoma.

questions.text: Match the incorrect pair regarding secondary glaucoma:

options.label: A
options.text: Phacotopic glaucoma- anterior subluxation of lens

questions.correct_answer: C. Phacolytic glaucoma- angle closure glaucoma
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Phacolytic glaucoma- angle closure glaucoma Phacolytic glaucoma causes secondary open angle glaucoma if the lens has been damaged or if lens proteins from a hypermature senile cataract escape into the aqueous. Cortical lens matter excites a reaction by phagocytes, which engulf the lens particles. These cells are swept into the trabecular spaces by the normal current of aqueous, where they block the exit of aqueous from the eye.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A. Phacotopic glaucoma occurs due to anterior subluxation or dislocation of the lens. In partial subluxation, a large segment of the angle of the anterior chamber may be compressed or blocked. In complete dislocation into the anterior chamber, the entire angle may be blocked, especially if the iris becomes firmly contracted over the posterior surface of the lens. Option: B. Phacomorphic glaucoma develops when the lens becomes intumescent, either by the rapid development of cataractous changes or after a traumatic rupture of its capsule. The swollen lens obliterates the drainage angle by forcing the root of the iris against the cornea. Option: D. Neovascular glaucoma follows extensive retinal ischaemia and is commonly seen in association with central retinal vein obstruction (CRVO) and proliferative diabetic retinopathy. It is due to the presence of neovascularization over the iris (rubeosis iridis) and consequent fibrosis, leading to zip-like adhesions of the iris to the cornea at the angle.

questions.text: Which of the following is incorrect about Fuchs heterochromic iridocyclitis?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Primary glaucoma Fuchs heterochromic iridocyclitis leads to secondary glaucoma since glaucoma develops secondary to inflammation from iritis and does not cause primary glaucoma.

Highyeild:

Fuchs heterochromic iridocyclitis is a rare form of chronic anterior uveitis. The exact cause of FHI is not fully known but is believed to be an autoimmune disorder.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Options: A and C. It also consists of chronic , low - grade iritis with posterior subcapsular cataract . It is associated with a change in the colour of the iris. The inflammation consists of low-grade flares and cells, with stellate keratic precipitates and fine filaments scattered over the entire endothelium. It is rare, unilateral in 90% of cases, and occurs between the third and fourth decades of life. Treatment consists of control of uveitis with topical corticosteroids and NSAIDS, medical management of raised intraocular pressure, and glaucoma therapy, which is reevaluated once the inflammation subsides completely, as per visual field loss.

Extraedge:

Treatment of FHI: c orticosteroid eye drops to reduce inflammation of the eye as well as other medications to control the immune response. In some cases, surgery may be necessary to remove cataracts or treat glaucoma.

questions.text: A 56-year-old man has been a known diabetic for 15 years. He has never had an ophthalmology review. On examination, his IOP is raised. On fundoscopy, dot and blot haemorrhages, hard exudates, and neovascularization are seen. What is the treatment for the condition?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

All of the above This is a case of neovascular glaucoma that follows extensive retinal ischaemia and is seen in association with central retinal vein obstruction (CRVO) and proliferative diabetic retinopathy. It is due to the presence of neovascularization over the iris (rubeosis iridis) and consequent fibrosis, leading to zip-like adhesions of the iris to the cornea at the angle.

Highyeild:

Treatment consists of anti-VEGF agents and retinal photocoagulation or cryotherapy to eliminate the stimulus for neovascularization. The raised intraocular pressure can be alleviated by a trabeculectomy, anti fibroblastic agents, or an anterior chamber drainage implant.

questions.text: Which is the mechanism behind corticosteroid induced glaucoma?

options.label: A
options.text: Depolymerization of glycosaminoglycans leads to narrowing of the trabecular openings.

options.label: B
options.text: Endothelial cells act as phagocytes and block trabecular meshwork

options.label: C
options.text: Increase prostaglandin raises the intraocular pressure

questions.correct_answer: B. Endothelial cells act as phagocytes and block trabecular meshwork
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Endothelial cells act as phagocytes and block trabecular meshwork Endothelial cells lining the trabecular meshwork act as phagocytes for debris in the aqueous humour, and with corticosteroids suppressing their activity, there is a further blockage of the trabecular meshwork and consequently decreased outflow.

Highyeild:

Symptoms include Blurred vision Halos around eyes Eye pain Redness in eyes

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A. Corticosteroids stabilize lysosomal membranes and inhibit the release of hydrolases, due to which glycosaminoglycans (present in the trabecular meshwork) cannot depolymerize and retain water in the extracellular space, which leads to narrowing of the trabecular openings. Option: C. Corticosteroids inhibit the synthesis of prostaglandins E And F, whose function is to lower the intraocular pressure by increasing the outflow facility.

Extraedge:

Treatment for corticosteroid induced glaucoma typically involves stopping or reducing the use of steroids. Regular eye examinations are recommended to check for any signs of increased eye pressure.
